raw_comment:
I notice that legacy students have a higher admissions rate than non legacy students no matter how wealthy they are. Whether you are legacy or not, your wealth provides you a significant advantage in getting in. Legacy students who are also wealthy see an even more significant boost in admission likelihood, around 7x than the average. I wonder if colleges had less monetary incentive  if the admissions rate for legacy students would be lower. Both of these factors can prevent average people who don't have historically wealthy families from climbing climbing the income ladder. 

Is legacy privilege unfair to average families?
ace_sentences: Legacy students have a higher admissions rate than non-legacy students.
This is true no matter how wealthy the students are.
A student can be a legacy student or a non-legacy student.
A student's wealth provides the student a significant advantage in admission.
A legacy student who is wealthy has an even more significant increase in admission likelihood.
This increase is about 7 times higher than the average admission likelihood.
If colleges have less monetary incentive, then the admissions rate for legacy students might be lower.
Legacy status and wealth are factors.
These factors can prevent average people from climbing the income ladder.
Some average people do not have historically wealthy families.
The question is: Is legacy privilege unfair to average families?
